chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Consider if there are features of an alternative diagnosis.
  • Ask about associated symptoms which may suggest an underlying head or neck cancer, including:
    • Unilateral nasal bleeding and/or severe nasal obstruction.
    • Change in voice character and/or unexplained hoarseness.
    • Dysphagia.
    • Unusually rapid onset of symptoms in the absence of marked weight gain.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Head and neck cancers - recognition and referral.
  • Ask about any risk factors for obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS).
  • Ask about the effects of daytime sleepiness on driving and work performance, relationships, mood, sleeping, and social life. In children, ask about school performance, concentration, behaviour, and growth.
  • Take a collateral history from a partner, if possible, regarding snoring habits, apnoeas, and choking episodes.
  • Examine for:
    • Enlarged tonsils.
    • Small jaw.
    • Nasal blockage (for example due to polyps or a deviated nasal septum).
    • Signs of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, respiratory failure, or cor pulmonale (which may influence the urgency of referral).
  • Check the person's blood pressure, body mass index (BMI), and neck circumference (collar size).
  • Ask the person to complete an Epworth sleepiness questionnaire, to assess the extent and severity of symptoms.
  • Consider arranging investigations if an underlying cause is suspected (for example thyroid function tests if hypothyroidism is suspected).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Epworth sleepiness questionnaire
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• An Epworth sleepiness questionnaire, which measures perception of sleepiness, is helpful in the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS). The Epworth Sleepiness Score (ESS) is calculated using eight questions, each scored 0–3, which assess the tendency of a person to fall asleep in a variety of situations:
    • How likely are you to doze or fall asleep in the following situations, in contrast to just feeling tired?
      • Sitting and reading.
      • Watching television.
      • Sitting, inactive in a public place (for example at the theatre or in a meeting).
      • As a passenger in a car for an hour without a break.
      • Lying down to rest in the afternoon when circumstances permit.
      • Sitting and talking to someone.
      • Sitting quietly after lunch without alcohol.
      • In a car, while stopped for a few minutes in traffic.
    • Each question is answered choosing from one of the following options:
      • Would never doze (0 points).
      • Slight chance of dozing (1 point).
      • Moderate chance of dozing (2 points).
      • High chance of dozing (3 points).
  • A total score greater than 10 indicates abnormal daytime sleepiness:
    • Mild (11–14).
    • Moderate (15–18).
    • Severe (more than 18).
  • The questionnaire can be accessed at www.britishsnoring.co.uk.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Management of obstructive sleep apnoea/hypopnoea syndrome (OSAHS) in adults [SIGN, 2003] and expert opinion in review articles [Attarian and Sabri, 2002; Parker et al, 2005; Powell et al, 2010; Greenstone and Hack, 2014].

  • Seeking information from a bed partner is useful, as a person with obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS) may fail to recognize or downplay symptoms.
  • Daytime sleepiness helps differentiate OSAS from primary snoring. An Epworth sleepiness questionnaire, which measures the person's perception of sleepiness, is helpful in the diagnosis and in stratifying the severity of OSAS.
